t:intro.p: A receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curve shows the performance of a binary classification model as its discrimination threshold varies. For a range of thresholds, the curve plots the true positive rate against the false positive rate.

The Receiver Operating Characteristic (ROC) function takes a set of prediction-actual pairs for a binary classification model and calculates the following values for a range of discrimination thresholds:
True positive rate (TPR)
False positive rate (FPR)
Area under the ROC curve (AUC)
Gini coefficient

A prediction-actual pair for a binary classifier consists of:
Predicted probability that an observation is in the positive class
Actual class of the observation

A discrimination threshold determines whether an observation is classified as positive (1) or negative (0). For example, suppose that a model predicts that an observation will be classified as positive with 0.55 probability. If the threshold above which an observation is classified as positive is 0.5, then the observation is classified as positive. If the threshold is 0.6, the observation is classified as negative.

You can create prediction-actual pairs for ROC with these functions:
AdaBoostPredict
DecisionForestPredict_MLE
DecisionTreePredict_MLE
GLMPredict_MLE
XGBoostPredict

pre.tt: SELECT * FROM ROC ( ON { table | view | (query) } AS InputTable { OUT TABLE OutputTable (output_table) | OUT TABLE ROCTable (ROC_table) } USING [ ModelIDColumn ('model_id_column')] ProbabilityColumn ('probability_column') ObservationColumn ('observation_column') PositiveClass ('positive_class_label') [ NumThresholds (num_thresholds)] [ ROCValues ({'true'|'t'|'yes'|'y'|'1'|'false'|'f'|'no'|'n'|'0'}) ] [ AUC ({'true'|'t'|'yes'|'y'|'1'|'false'|'f'|'no'|'n'|'0'}) ] [ Gini ({'true'|'t'|'yes'|'y'|'1'|'false'|'f'|'no'|'n'|'0'}) ] ) AS alias;

div.dd: [Required if you omit ROCTable, disallowed otherwise.] Specify the name for the output table that the function creates. The output_table must not already exist.
[Required if you omit OutputTable, disallowed otherwise.] Specify the name for the ROC table that the function creates. The ROC_table must not already exist.

[Optional] Specify the name of the InputTable column that contains the model or partition identifiers for the ROC curves.
Note: Use this syntax element only when InputTable contains information for more than one model. The function creates a separate ROC curve for each model identifier in this column. Each model must include exactly two classes in ObservationColumn.
Specify the name of the InputTable column that contains the predictions.
Specify the name of the InputTable column that contains the actual classes.
Specify the label of the positive class.
[Optional] Specify the number of thresholds for the function to use. The num_thresholds must be a NUMERIC value in the range [1, 10000].
Default: 50 (The function uniformly distributes the thresholds between 0 and 1.)
[Optional with OutputTable, disallowed with ROCTable.] Specify whether the function displays ROC values (thresholds, false positive rates, and true positive rates).
[Optional with OutputTable, disallowed with ROCTable.] Specify whether the function displays the AUC calculated from the ROC values.

[Optional with OutputTable, disallowed with ROCTable.] Specify whether the function displays the Gini coefficient calculated from the ROC values. The Gini coefficient is a measure of inequality among values of a frequency distribution. A Gini coefficient of 0 indicates that all values are the same. The closer the Gini coefficient is to 1, the more unequal are the values in the distribution.

p.p:
Note: If you specify OutputTable, the valid combinations of ROCValues, AUC, and Gini syntax elements are those that specify one of the following:
ROCValues only
AUC only
Gini only
AUC and Gini
The function issues an error message if you do any of the following:
Specify AUC only, Gini only, or AUC and Gini only, and ROCValues ('true').
(When specifying AUC only, Gini only, or AUC and Gini only, ROCValues is false by default.)
Specify an invalid combination (such as ROCValues ('true') and AUC ('true'), or all three 'false').
Specify ROCTable and also specify any of AUC, Gini, or ROCValues.

t:intro.p: The table has one row for each observation.

td.div: [Appears only with ModelIDColumn syntax element.] Model identifier or partition for ROC curve associated with observation.
Predicted probability that observation is in positive class.

t:intro.p: The output depends on whether you specify OutputTable or ROCTable.
If you specify OutputTable, the function outputs a message and creates OutputTable. The OutputTable schema depends on the ROCValues syntax element.
The table has one row for each threshold for each model, and contains only ROC values.

td.div: Same as model_id_column in input table
[Appears only with ModelIDColumn syntax element.] Model identifier or partition for ROC curve associated with observation, taken from model_id_column.
Threshold at which function classifies an observation as positive.
True positive rate for threshold (number of observations correctly predicted as positive based on threshold, divided by number of observations known to be positive).
False positive rate for threshold (number of observations incorrectly predicted as positive based on threshold, divided by number of observations known to be negative).

t:intro.p: Note: This is the default output table if you specify AUC only, Gini only, or AUC and Gini only.

The table has the following:
One row for each model
No ROC values
AUC values, Gini values, or both (depending on AUC and Gini syntax elements)

td.div: Same as model_id_column in input table
[Appears only with ModelIDColumn syntax element.] Model identifier or partition for ROC curve associated with observation, taken from model_id_column.
Area under ROC curve for data in partition. With AUC ( 'false'), this value is NULL.
Gini coefficient for ROC curve for data in partition. With Gini ('false'), this value is NULL.

t:intro.p: If you specify ROCTable, the function outputs a table to the screen and creates ROCTable.

td.div: Same as model_id_column in input table
[Appears only with ModelIDColumn syntax element.] Model identifier or partition for ROC curve associated with observation, taken from model_id_column.
Area under ROC curve for data in partition.
Gini coefficient for ROC curve for data in partition.

t:intro.p: Same as default OutputTable Schema in ROC Output with OutputTable.
The input table has data from four different models, each of which outputs the same probability for each observation.
In this call, the ROCValues, AUC, and Gini syntax elements default to the values 'true', 'false', and 'false', respectively.

pre.tt: SELECT * FROM ROC( ON roctable AS InputTable OUT TABLE OutputTable(rocoutput20) USING ModelIdColumn('model') ProbabilityColumn('probability') ObservationColumn('obs') PositiveClass('p') NumThresholds(100) ) AS dt;

t:intro.p: Download a zip file of all examples and a SQL script file that creates their input tables from the download tab in the left pane.
This example uses AUC values to check the performance of the model used in ROC Example: OutputTable, Default Values.
The input table is roctable, as in ROC Example: OutputTable, Default Values.
Because this call specifies AUC ('true') and omits the ROCValues syntax element, the ROCValues syntax element has the value 'false'.

pre.tt: SELECT * FROM ROC( ON roctable AS InputTable OUT TABLE OutputTable(rocoutput21) USING ModelIdColumn('model') ProbabilityColumn('probability') ObservationColumn('obs') PositiveClass('p') NumThresholds(100) AUC('true') ) AS dt;
model auc gini ----- ----- ---- 1 0.375 NULL 2 0.375 NULL 3 0.375 NULL 4 0.375 NULL

t:intro.p: The AUC values are less than 0.5, which means that the model performs worse than random guessing, and you must change it before you use it for prediction. Compare these AUC values to the AUC value in the ROC Example: OutputTable, AUC ('true'), Gini ('true') output.
Download a zip file of all examples and a SQL script file that creates their input tables from the download tab in the left pane.
Because this call specifies AUC ('true') and Gini ('true') and omits the ROCValues syntax element, the ROCValues syntax element has the value 'false'.

pre.tt: SELECT * FROM ROC( ON iris AS InputTable OUT TABLE OutputTable(irisout18) USING ProbabilityColumn('prob2') ObservationColumn('obs') NumThresholds(100) PositiveClass('2') AUC('true') Gini('true') ) AS dt;

t:intro.p: The AUC value is much greater than 0.5, which means the model performs well and you can use it for prediction.
Download a zip file of all examples and a SQL script file that creates their input tables from the download tab in the left pane.
The input table is roctable, as in ROC Example: OutputTable, Default Values.

pre.tt: SELECT * FROM ROC( ON roctable AS InputTable OUT TABLE ROCTable(rocoutput20) USING ModelIdColumn('model') ProbabilityColumn('probability') ObservationColumn('obs') PositiveClass('p') NumThresholds(100) ) AS dt;

t:intro.p: Onscreen:
The ROCTable, rocoutput20, is the same as the OutputTable in ROC Example: OutputTable, Default Values.
Download a zip file of all examples and a SQL script file that creates their input tables from the download tab in the left pane.
